sentences: Oluwatosin Ajibade (born 19 July 1991), better known by his stage name Mr Eazi, is a Nigerian singer, songwriter, and entrepreneur.
section: N/A

sentences: He is a pioneer of Banku music, a fusion of sound he describes as a mixture of Ghanaian highlife and Nigerian chord progressions and patterns.
section: N/A

sentences: Mr Eazi relocated to Kumasi, Ghana in 2008 and enrolled at KNUST, where he began booking artists to perform at college parties.
section: N/A

sentences: He showed interest in music after recording a guest verse on "My Life", a song that gained traction and became a popular record at KNUST.
section: N/A

section: N/A

== Early life and education ==

sentences: Early life and education
section: == Early life and education ==
== Early life and education ==

sentences: Mr Eazi was born in Port Harcourt, the capital and largest city in Rivers State, Nigeria.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He grew up in an entrepreneurial home.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: His mother owned a small business and his father is a pilot.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: The latter parent established his own private aviation consulting practice.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: While attending primary school in Lagos, Mr Eazi had a brief stint in the school's choir.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: During his upbringing, he listened to records his dad would play for the family while having breakfast.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: At age 16, Mr Eazi relocated to Ghana to further his educational endeavors, enrolling in the mechanical engineering program at Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST).
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: Mr Eazi started recording music during his time at KNUST.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He contributed guest vocals to the track "My Life", a song that gained traction and became a popular record at KNUST.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: Prior to that, he established a party and promotion company called Swagger Entertainment.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He used this platform to book shows and promote events on the campus of KNUST.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: When he was 23 years old, he returned to Nigeria and opened his own e-commerce platform.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: Mr Eazi told The Guardian newspaper he briefly worked for Schlumberger when he returned to Nigeria.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He also told the aforementioned newspaper his business ventures included soft drinks import, gold mining, and food distribution.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He told Highsnobiety he started about six business ventures.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: In 2014, Mr Eazi quit being a club promoter after an artist failed to show up for the largest party he attempted to throw.
section: == Early life and education ==
== Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases =
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===
== Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: Mr Eazi released his 13-track debut mixtape About to Blow in July 2013.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: It produced two singles: "Pipi Dance" and "Bankulize".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: The former was released in mid-2012, while the latter was released in 2013.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: Mr Eazi recorded the mixtape with producer Klu and released it within a week.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: The Fader magazine descrie mixtape as a "heavily dancehall-leaning SoundCloud playlist".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: Prior to releasing the mixtape, Mr Eazi worked with producers such as Magnom, Peeweezle, Nshona, Klumonsta, D'Tunes, and E-Kelly.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: Moreover, he was featured on Stay Jay's "Baby Lace" and Lousika's "Knockout".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: In 2014, Mr Eazi relocated to Nigeria.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: He was contacted by UK-based Ghanaian producer Juls, who got a hold of some of his recordings.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: Due to not being able to locate the audio files of his old recordings, Mr Eazi's attempt at working with Juls stalled for a long time.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: Mr Eazi eventually retrieved his audio files and sent them to Juls, who made a new beat and created the artwork for the mixtape's second single "Bankulize".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: The song features vocals from Ghanaian hiplife artist Pappy Kojo and was released in November 2014.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: The official remix of "Bankulize" features Burna Boy and was released in September 2016.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: Mr Eazi premiered the remix on Ebro Darden's Beats 1 radio show a month earlier.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: In August 2015, Mr Eazi released the dancehall-influenced track "Skin Tight".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: It features guest vocals from Ghanaian singer Efya and was produced by DJ Juls.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: In an interview with Complex magazine, Mr Eazi described the song as a "fusion".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: He said he spoke Ghanaian pidgin on the delivery and used Nigerian melodies.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: In August 2016, Nigerian record producer Cobhams Asuquo released a rendition of the song.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: DJ Caise released a house remix of the song in September 2016, while Terry G collaborated with Mr Eazi to release a remix of the song.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: In April 2017, "Skin Tight" was featured in an ad for the vodka brand Ciroc.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: Mr Eazi was featured on Eugy's 2016 hit single "Dance for Me".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: The Guardian newspaper included the song on its list of the 10 biggest African tracks of 2016.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: The music video for "Dance for Me" was directed by Vertex and Gabriella Kingsely.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: Robin Murray of Clash magazine described the song as a "salute to their joint Ghanaian heritage".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: On 17 June 2016, Mr Eazi released the R&B-inspired "Anointing", a song that features rap vocals from Ghanaian rapper Sarkodie.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===

sentences: Mr Eazi first announced plans for the song in May 2016.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2013–2015: About to Blow and other releases ===
== Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===
== Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: In February 2016, organizers of the Vodafone-sponsored Ghana Music Awards made a decision not to nominate Mr Eazi in any of its Ghanaian-only categories.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: According to George Quaye, a spokesperson for Charterhouse, Mr Eazi was disqualified because of his nationality.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: Quaye also stated that Mr Eazi was only eligible to compete in the African Artiste of the Year category.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: However, he failed to pick up a nomination in the aforementioned category because the organizers felt that he isn't as big as the other nominees.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: On 11 January 2017, Mr Eazi tweeted that Ghanaian music has a great influence over present-day Nigerian music.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: He received heavy backlash after posting the tweet and trended nationwide in both Ghana and Nigeria.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: On 12 January 2017, Mr Eazi apologized to Nigerians for the comments that he made.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: Following his performance at the 2016 Ghana Music Awards, Wizkid announced that he signed Mr Eazi to his imprint Starboy Entertainment.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: However, Mr Eazi told Star FM Ghana in July 2017 that he is not officially signed to Starboy.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: He also told Star FM Ghana that he is only in business with the imprint.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: Mr Eazi's second mixtape, Life Is Eazi, Vol.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: 1 – Accra To Lagos, was released on 10 February 2017.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: The mixtape was initially scheduled for release on 11 February 2017.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: It debuted at number 4 on the Billboard World Albums chart.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: The mixtape comprises 14 tracks, including three bonus tracks.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: Guest artists featured on the mixtape include Tekno, Olamide, Phyno, Mugeez, Medikal, DJ Cuppy, Falz, and Big Lean.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: Its production was handled by Maleek Berry, Masterkraft, Legendury Beatz, and Young John.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: Mr Eazi announced on Instagram that the mixtape sold 200,000 copies in pre-orders.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: While speaking to Julie Adenuga on her Beats 1 radio show, he said the mixtape is a tribute to the two cities that influenced the evolution of his sound.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: The mixtape's lead single "Leg Over" was produced by E-Kelly and released on 2 December 2016.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: The music video for "Leg Over" features cameo appearances from comedian Eddie Kadi, Maleek Berry, and Wizkid.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: Mr Eazi told Lawrence Burney from Noisey.com that the song is about being taken advantage of in a relationship.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: He also said the song was leaked and wasn't meant to be a single.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: Upon its release in December 2016, "Leg Over" inspired numerous dance videos.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: Gabriel Myers Hansen, a critic and editor whose review was posted on the Music In Africa website, described the song as "gentle and minimalist".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: Hansen also said it is "freshened by delicate string and percussion placements reminiscent of highlife from decades ago".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: On 1 February 2017, Mr Eazi released "Tilapia" as the mixtape's second single.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: It features vocals from Ghanaian hip hop artist Medikal.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: On 1 March 2017, Mr Eazi released the Sesan-directed music video for "In The Morning".
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: The song features vocals from Toronto rapper Big Lean.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: On 1 April 2017, Mr Eazi released the Teekay-directed music video for "Fight", a song that features additional vocals from DJ Cuppy.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2016–2017: GMA snub, Twitter backlash, Accra to Lagos, and record deal ===

sentences: On 7 April 2017, Mr Eazi released the music video for "Business", a song that features vocals from Mugeez of R2Bees.

sentences: Coachella and Empawa Africa ===
section: == Early life and education == | === 2019: Coachella and Empawa Africa ===

sentences: In January 2019, it was announced that Mr Eazi will be performing at the 2019 Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2019: Coachella and Empawa Africa ===

sentences: In August 2019, Mr Eazi launched emPawa Africa, a talent incubation initiative designed to nurture and support up-and-coming African artists.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2019: Coachella and Empawa Africa ===

sentences: Thirty musicians would be enrolled in the first edition and would receive grant and mentorship to scale up their music career.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2019: Coachella and Empawa Africa ===

sentences: The initiative is also supported by YouTube Music.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2019: Coachella and Empawa Africa ===

sentences: In January 2021, Ajibade announced his upcoming EP titled Something Else, set for a 19 February release.
section: == Early life and education == | === 2019: Coachella and Empawa Africa ===
== Artistry ==

sentences: Artistry ==
section: == Artistry ==

sentences: Mr Eazi is known for pioneering Banku music, a sound "characterized by percolating rhythms and laid-back vocal delivered in Ghanaian Pidgin English".
section: == Artistry ==

sentences: Mr Eazi's music largely fits into the category of Afrobeats, a contemporary West African pop genre that marries global pop, Dancehall, highlife, and hip-hop.
section: == Artistry ==

sentences: Mr Eazi's music has been described as having an R&B-like quality reminiscent of artists such as Beres Hammond and Gregory Isaacs.
section: == Artistry ==

sentences: Lawrence Burney from Noisey.com stated that Mr Eazi uses his deep voice to "give ballad-like qualities to dance-forward production".
section: == Artistry ==
